questions.question: A young woman delivered her baby on the way to the hospital. While examining her, younotice a perineal tear. This injury could have been prevented by all except:

options.C: Slow delivery of the head in between contractions

questions.question: What is the most common cause of true cephalopelvic disproportion in India?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of true cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) in India is rickets.The most common cause of true CPD in developing countries is vitamin D deficiency and rickets.In developed countries, it is trauma to the pelvis. It occurs due to pelvic dystocia (larger fetus andsmaller pelvis).Relative CPD is the most common type of CPD. It is caused due to fetal malposition(occipitoposterior position/brow presentation).

questions.question: You are monitoring uterine contractions in a term primigravida in labor. You find that thecontractions are uncoordinated and the frequency is about 8 contractions every 10 minutes.Which of the following is incorrect regarding your finding?

options.B: It is common in nulliparous labour
options.D: Management includes wait and watch policy

questions.explanation: The given clinical finding is suggestive of uterine tachysystole. Oxytocin administration is notbeneficial here as it leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus.Tachysystole (hypertonic uterine dysfunction):212• The uterine contractions are uncoordinated and increased in frequency (>5 contractions in 10minutes)• Contractions occur with an increase in the baseline tone without rest in between them• It is associated with late active phase dysfunction i.e., when the cervix is almost 7 cm dilated•The most common cause is occipito-posterior position. Hence, a wait and watch policy isadopted• It is more common in nulliparous females•Oxytocin administration leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus and is not recommended.Hypotonic uterine dysfunction:•• Uterine contractions are inadequate• It is associated with early active phase• It is more common in nulliparous females.

questions.question: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cmdilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?205

options.B: Augmentation with oxytocinCesarean sectiond) AmniotomyQuestion 5:A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman presents to the ER with hypotension and severe abdominalpain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable over the abdomen. USG abdomen revealed alarge uterine wall defect. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?a) Maternal bradycardiab) Fetal bradycardia

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either false labor pain or prolonged latent phase. Theappropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.False labor can be differentiated from the latent phase of labor by therapeutic rest i.e., the patientis sedated with morphine.Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic restcontinue to be in prolonged latent phase.There is no indication of cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion ispresent. Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phase.

questions.question: A young primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation came with complaints of decreased perceptionof fetal movements for the past 2 days. NST is non-reactive and on ultrasound fetal cardiacactivity is absent. What will be the best management in this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of intrauterine fetal death (IUFD). The best managementfor such cases at 36 weeks is waiting for spontaneous expulsion.Forceps extraction is only necessary if spontaneous expulsion doesn't take place.Artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is not done due to the risk of infections. Cesarean sectionis avoided as far as possible in case of fetal death.Waiting till term is not recommended in cases of uterine infections, disseminated intravascularcoagulation, and psychological upset.

questions.question: A G2P1L0 woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation for a routine visit. She mentionsthat she has a history of prior stillbirth at 37 weeks. What is the best time for delivery in thispatient?
questions.explanation: The best time for elective delivery in patients with a history of previous stillbirth is 39 weeks,either by induction or cesarean section.The recommendations for the management of subsequent pregnancy after stillbirth is as follows:⚫ Ultrasonographic screening for fetal growth restriction after 28 weeks••• Kick counts starting from 28 weeks of gestation• Antepartum fetal surveillance starting at 32 weeks or 1-2 weeks earlier than prior stillbirth•Support and reassuranceLabor induction is suitable in such cases. Cesarean delivery is done for those with acontraindication to induction.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigationsreveal fetal demise. What will be the management?
questions.explanation: The best management in the given clinical scenario is cesarean section.Obstructive labor management involves administering intravenous fluids to correct dehydration,providing antibiotics to prevent infection, and promptly performing a cesarean section to relievethe obstruction. If the fetus is alive, an immediate cesarean section is typically performed.Management of obstructed labor never involves a wait-and-watch approach or augmenting withoxytocin.Clinical features of obstructed labor include maternal exhaustion, dehydration, tachycardia,tachypnea, genital sepsis, postpartum hemorrhage, and shock.214On P/A examination the upper uterine segment is tender and tonically contracted. The loweruterine segment is thin and stretched. A groove/depression is felt between the upper uterinesegment and the lower uterine segment. This is called a Bandls ring.Complications of obstructed labor include rupture of the uterus and vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.question: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?

options.D: Cesarean sectionFoetal Heart Rate2001901801701601501401301201101009080Amniotic Fluid CMoulding 1+109Cervix Plot (X)860C0CB BBB2+M3+MAlertActionDorsalof head3Hours5432105 •12N345678910111213Time 10am11am 12pm 1pm2pm3pm 4pm5pmContractionsper 10 minutes543 21OMARROW

questions.explanation: The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section.There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. Thepatient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconiumand there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions inobstructed labor.Forceps can be applied only when the cervix is fully dilated and the head is low down.

questions.question: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performedhas extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures islikely to be injured in this case?207
questions.explanation: External anal sphincter is the structure injured in an episiotomy extended posteriorly beyond theperineal body.Perineal tear have been divided into four degrees:• First degree- laceration is restricted to the skin of the fourchette•Second degree- muscles of the perineal body are torn through•Third degree- the tear extends partially backward through the external sphincter of the anus• Fourth degree- the external anal sphincter is torn and anal mucosa is also involvedA central tear of the perineum is when the head penetrates first through the posterior vaginalwall, then through the perineal body and appears through the skin of the perineum. It usuallyoccurs in patients with a contracted outlet.

questions.question: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that the cord isprolapsed. What should be the next immediate step of management?

options.A: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina.
options.B: Inform the doctor and shift to OT
options.D: Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.explanation: In this scenario the midwife should put the pregnant women in a Trendelenburg position or in anexaggerated and elevated Sims' position with a pillow or wedge under the hip or thigh.Caesarean section is the recommended treatment of choice for cord prolapse. Prior to performingthe procedure, several measures can be taken to alleviate cord compression. These measuresinvolve:• Manually elevating the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the entire hand through thevagina215•Positioning the patient in steep Trendelenburg, exaggerated Sim's position, or knee-chestposition•Filling the bladder with 500-700 cc or more of saline (known as the Vagos method)After the diagnosis of cord prolapse is made, it is crucial not to attempt cord replacement. Suchattempts are not only ineffective but also result in the inevitable rupture of the membranes,leading to cord prolapse.Scheme of Management of Cord ProlapseBaby aliveCesarean delivery(treatment of choice)Cord prolapseBaby livingor dead- Maturity of the baby• Cervical dilatationBaby dead• Confirm with ultrasoundWait for spontaneous deliveryor⚫ Destructive operationImmediate vaginaldelivery not possibleVortexForceps orVentouseImmediate safevaginal deliverypossibleBreechBreech extraction inexpert hands onlyFirst aid- Bladder fillingTo lift the presenting part off the cordPosture - exaggerated and elevated Simsposition or Trendelenburg or Knee chest position- to refer to an equipped hospitalDefinitemanagementCesarean sectionOMARROW

questions.question: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour,reveals retraction ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment.Which would best describe this ring?
questions.explanation: Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour.The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome theobstruction while the lower segment dilates.With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting uppersegment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressivelystretched and becomes thinner.The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.216Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localizedspastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicioususe of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

questions.question: A 26-year-old term primigravida presents to the clinic for a regular check-up. Onexamination, uterus corresponds to term and head of the fetus is non-engaged. What is themost common cause for this finding?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of non-engagement at term in a primigravida is deflexed head followedby cephalopelvic disproportion.Non-engagement at the onset of active phase of labour is a risk factor for caesarean section.The problems of prolonged labour are that the woman is exposed to high risk of infection, ketosisand obstructed labour while the fetus faces the danger of asphyxia and infection.217

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cardinal movement occurring during labor?
questions.explanation: Asynclitism is not a cardinal movement during labor.Asynclitism refers to the position of a baby in the uterus such that the head of the baby ispresenting first and is tilted to the shoulder. This causes the fetal head to no longer be in line withthe birth canal.Moderate degrees of asynclitism are the rule in normal labor. However, if severe, this condition isa common reason for cephalopelvic disproportion even with an otherwise normal sized pelvis.Asynclitism can be of 2 types:•• When the sagittal suture lies anteriorly, the posterior parietal bone becomes the leadingpresenting part and is called posterior asynclitism.• When the sagittal suture lies posteriorly, the anterior parietal bone becomes the leadingpresenting part and is called anterior asynclitism.MAsynclitismMMAnteriorparietalAnterior asynclitismSagittalNormal synolitismPosteriorparietalPosterior asynclitism@MARROWOccipitofrontalplanePelvicinlet plane

questions.question: A 28-year-old primigravida is brought to the labour room in the latent phase of labor. Howlong willyou wait till you declare her latent phase to be prolonged?
questions.explanation: •Latent phase is said to be prolonged in a primigravida if it lasts for more than 20 hours.Friedman defined prolonged latent phase as:A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase• A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase

questions.question: All of the following findings are seen in the partogram of a patient except:

options.B: Arrest of descentFoetal Heart Rate2001901801701601501401301201101009080Amniotic Fluid C C CMoulding 1+10Cervix Plot (X)098765432-09Dorsalof head 36Contractions0CB BBB2+M3+MAlertActionHours12345678910111213Time 10am 11am 12pm 1pm2pm3pm 4pm5pmper 10 minutes45 3 2-MARROW209

questions.explanation: The above partogram shows secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hour, arrest of descent for>1 hour and a fall in fetal heart rate suggestive of fetal distress.218These are characteristic findings of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section.

questions.question: A 26-year-old primigravida presents with labour pains. At 39 weeks of gestation, she wasdiagnosed with prolonged phase of labour. Which of the following is false regarding thiscondition?

options.C: Excessive sedation can prolong this phase

questions.explanation: The given clinical features suggest that the patient is in latent phase of labor. Latent phase is saidto be prolonged if it is:• >20 h in nullipara•>14 h in multiparaCauses of prolonged latent phase:•Excessive sedation/epidural analgesia•• Poor cervical conditions (thick, uneffaced)• False labour (most common cause in multipara)Friedman's curve is used in the diagnosis of prolonged labour. It is the sigmoid curve plotting thepattern of cervical dilatation during the latent and active phase of normal labour.1000Cervical Dilation, cm(D4Accel.PhaseMARREANPhaseof max.slopeDecel.Phase202Latent phase6Time, hrSec.phaseActive phase8101214©MARROWManagement includes morphine administration, rest and oxytocin stimulation.

questions.question: Protracted active phase dilation in a multiparous woman is when cervical dilation is
questions.explanation: Protracted active phase dilation in a multiparous woman is when cervical dilation is less than 1.5 cm/hour.

questions.question: Which among the following is false with respect to active phase of labor?

options.A: The minimum rate of cervical dilatation is 1.2cm/hr in nullipara
options.B: Arrest of dilatation is cessation of dilatation for >2 hours
options.C: Arrest of descent is cessation of descent for >1 hour
options.D: Poor cervical dilatation causes prolonged active phase

questions.explanation: 219Poor cervical dilatation causes a prolonged latent phase.Arrest of cervical dilatation is defined as the lack of cervical dilatation for ≥ 2 hours during theactive phase of labour.According to the Obstetric Care Consensus Committee, when cervical dilatation has reached ≥ 6cm with ruptured membranes, and there is no cervical change despite 4 hours of adequate uterinecontractions or 6 hours of inadequate contractions, a cesarean delivery is warranted.

questions.question: Protracted descent in labor in a nullipara is
questions.explanation: The protracted descent in labor in a nullipara is less than 1 cm/hour.

questions.question: A multigravida is posted for C-section due to arrest of descent in labor. It is defined as nodescent for
questions.explanation: Arrest of descent in labor in a multigravida is no descent for more than 1 hour.220
